entry.title: HK entrepot & JP occupation
entry.content:
• Entrepot
    • Unfavourable factors
    • Favourable factors
  • Japanese invasion
    • Timeline
      • World
      • Hong Kong
    • Reason
  • Hong Kong during Japanese occupation
    • Administration
      • Military rule
      • Districk administration
      • Policy of rule
    • Economic policies
      • Issuing military notes
      • Control over economic activities
      • Food Rationing
      • Forced Repatriation
    • Education and social policies
      • Japanization
      • Control over the mass media
  • Time Line

Notion
PDFï¼šOnedrive Github

Entrepot

  • Good geography condition
  • Free-port policy
  • The opening of the Suez Canal in 1869

Unfavourable factors

  • Labour movements
    • Seamen's Skrike æµ·å‘˜å¤§ç½¢å·¥
    • Carton-Hong Kong General Strike and Boycott çœæ¸¯å¤§ç½¢å·¥
  • Great Depression
    • American stock market collapsed

Favourable factors

  • Population growth
  • Commonwealth tax concessions è‹±è”é‚¦ç¨åŠ¡ä¼˜æƒ 
    • Ottawa Agreement æ¸¥å¤ªååå®š

Japanese invasion

Timeline

World

  • 1937, Full-scale invasion
  • 1941, Attacked the American naval base of Pearl Harbour

Hong Kong

JT = Japanese Troops / forces
NT = the New Territories

  1. 8/12 JT crossed Shenzhen river.
  2. 11/12 JT broke the defence line at Lap Sap Bay and captured NT
  3. 13/12 JT captured Kowloon & British troops retreated to Hong Kong Island.
  4. 18/12 JT landed HK Island
  5. 25/12 Governor Mark Young surrendered to Japan

Reason

  • Stop Hong Kong's supplies to the mainland China
  • invade Southeast Asia ï¼† Pacific regions
  • A midway station for supplies

Hong Kong during Japanese occupation

O.G. = Japanese occupation government
JP = Japanese
CN = Chinese

Administration

Military rule

  • JP set up a temporary military government ä¸´æ—¶å†›æ”¿åºœ
  • O.G.
    • Governor â†’ Isogai Rensuke çŸ¶è°·å»‰ä»‹
    • Important offices â†’ JP
    • The headquarters building â†’ The Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation
      • in Central ä¸­ç¯

Districk administration

  • Divided into 3 administration regions è¡Œæ”¿åŒº
    • Subdivided into 28 districts
      • The district bureau åŒºæ”¿æ‰€
        • The heads and deputy heads â†’ CN
        • Aim
          • tighten control over HK & CN

Policy of rule

  • O.G. appointed Chinese leaders

    â†’ Two Chinese consultative councils

    â†’ chiefs of district

    â†“To

    • Help O.G. implement å®æ–½ easily
    • Reduce the anti-Japanese sentiment åæ—¥æƒ…ç»ª

  • Prison Camp

    • British soldiers & officals

  • O.G. encouraged the Indian

    • organize anti-colonial åæ®–æ°‘ activities

    â†“To

    • weaken British rule

Economic policies

Issuing military notes

  • aim
    • Get resource to support the war
  • Action
    • 1947/7 Only used M.N. (M.N. = Military Note)
    • M.N. â†’ official currency
  • Problem
    • O.G. over-issued è¶…å‘ M.N.
      • M.N. depreciated è´¬å€¼
        • serious ä¸¥é‡çš„ inflation é€šè´§è†¨èƒ€

Control over economic activities

  • O.G. control the territory's trade åŒºåŸŸè´¸æ˜“ & business

  • Setted up a business

    • apply ç”³è¯· to the O.G.

  • Chinese-owned factories & shops

    • Re-open in 1942

    â†“ But

    • Closed down å€’é—­
      • Shortage of raw materials

Food Rationing

  • get food buying tickets from district bureau every month
    • 1 ticket â†’ 6.4 taels (0.24 kg) of rice
    • small amount of salt, oil, sugar and flour
  • 1944, rationing system was abolished åºŸé™¤
    • why?
      • food shortage became more serious
  • Result
    • died of starvation é¥¥é¥¿
      • why?
        • serious inflation
        • food shortage

Forced Repatriation

  • Aim
    • Solve the problem of shortage of food and resources
  • Action
    • Reduce the population
      • Local Chinese were forced to return to the mainland
  • Result

    • Population:

      • 1941â†’ 1.6 millions

      â†“5 years later (Reduced 1 million)

      • 1945 â†’ 0.6 millions

Education and social policies

Japanization

  • Aim
    • spread JP culture
    • uproot Western cultural influence
  • Action for enforced Japanization
    • Japanese replaced English as official language.
    • School
      • taught the Japanese language & culture
      • saluted the JP flag
      • Sang JP national anthem.
    • Constructed å»ºé€  Japanese-style building.
    • Demolished æ‹†æ¯ Western-style buildings & English signs.
    • Buildings, streets & districts â†’ JP names
      • Replace old CN & EN names

Control over the mass media

  • spread pro-Japanese messages

Time Line

entry.title: Maths
entry.content:
• Ch.7 LinearEquations in Two Unknowns
    • 7.1 Linear Equations in Two Unknowns and Their Graphs

Ch.7 LinearEquations in Two Unknowns

School's Note

7.1 Linear Equations in Two Unknowns and Their Graphs

  1. ï¼ˆnot a solutionï¼‰

Determine whether the following pairs are solutions of the equation (eg. 2x+y=42x+y=42x+y=4 )
e.g. (4,0)

Solution:

Sub. (4,0) into the equation
L.H.S. = 2(4)+0
          = 8
          â‰  R.H.S.
âˆµ L.H.S.  â‰  R.H.S.
âˆ´ (4,0) is not a solution of the equation.
  1. (is a solution)

Determine whether the following pairs are solutions of the equation (eg. 2x+y=42x+y=42x+y=4 )
e.g. (3,-2)

Solution:

Sub. (3,-2) into the equation.
L.H.S. =2(3)+(-2)
          =6-2
          =4
          =R.H.S.
âˆµ L.H.S.  = R.H.S.
âˆ´ (3,-2) is a solution of the equation.
